etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘crush to a powder’): of Germanic origin; related to German stampfen ‘stamp with the foot’; reinforced by Old French estamper ‘to stamp’. Compare with stomp

definitions: bring down (one's foot) heavily on the ground or on something on the ground

examples.text: he stamped his foot in frustration
he threw his cigarette down and stamped on it
Robertson stamped on all these suggestions

shortDefinitions: bring down one's foot heavily on ground or on something on ground

definitions: crush, flatten, or remove with a heavy blow from one's feet

examples.text: she stamped the snow from her boots

shortDefinitions: crush, flatten, or remove with heavy blow from one's foot

examples.text: John stamped off, muttering

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

definitions: impress a pattern or mark, especially an official one, on (a surface, object, or document) using an engraved or inked block or die or other instrument

examples.text: the woman stamped my passport

shortDefinitions: impress pattern or mark on surface, object

definitions: impress (a pattern or mark) on something by engraving or inking

examples.text: a key with a number stamped on the shaft
it's one of those records that has ‘classic’ stamped all over it

shortDefinitions: impress pattern or mark with engraved or inked block or die

definitions: make (something) by cutting it out with a die or mold

examples.text: traditionally, medals are stamped with dies or cast from a mold
the knives are stamped out from a flat strip of steel

shortDefinitions: make something by cutting it out with die or mould

definitions: cause (a particular quality or characteristic) to have a strong or permanent effect on something

examples.text: he must be able to stamp his authority on the team
the whole place is mine which means I can stamp my personality on it

shortDefinitions: have strong or permanent effect on

definitions: reveal or mark out (someone) as having a particular quality or ability

examples.text: his style stamps him as a player to watch

shortDefinitions: reveal or mark out as having particular quality or ability

definitions: affix a postage stamp or stamps onto (a letter or package)

examples.text: Annie stamped the envelope for her

shortDefinitions: fix postage stamp or stamps on to

definitions: an instrument for stamping a pattern or mark, in particular an engraved or inked block or die.
shortDefinitions: instrument for stamping pattern or mark

definitions: a mark or pattern made by a stamping instrument, especially one indicating official validation or certification

examples.text: passports with visa stamps
the emperor gave them his stamp of approval

definitions: a characteristic or distinctive impression or quality

examples.text: the whole project has the stamp of authority
even the least expensive movie bore the stamp of the studio's style

shortDefinitions: characteristic or distinctive impression or quality

definitions: a particular class or type of person or thing

examples.text: empiricism of this stamp has been especially influential in British philosophy

shortDefinitions: particular class or type of person or thing

definitions: a small adhesive piece of paper stuck to something to show that an amount of money has been paid, in particular a postage stamp

examples.text: a first-class stamp

shortDefinitions: small adhesive piece of paper stuck to something

definitions: an act or sound of stamping with the foot

examples.text: the stamp of boots on the bare floor

shortDefinitions: act or sound of stamping with foot

definitions: a block for crushing ore in a stamp mill.
shortDefinitions: block for crushing ore in stamp mill
